Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Arrive at the polling station during designated voting hours
Situation2: Polls stay open all day and the voter has a light schedule.
Story: It’s Saturday morning, and my phone buzzes with a message from Mom: “Call us when you get a chance, sweetheart.” I know they expect me to check in, especially on weekends, just to let them know I’m okay. I glance at the clock—plenty of time before the polling station closes. I promised myself I’d vote today; it’s important, and I have no excuse not to go. But as I scroll through my texts, guilt creeps in. If I call my parents now, I’ll get caught up in a long conversation, and I might lose my momentum to leave the house. If I go vote first, I’ll be ignoring their message, and I know they’ll worry. I feel torn, pulled between being a good child and a responsible citizen. My parents just want to hear my voice, but my civic duty is calling too. I stand in the hallway, phone in one hand, voter ID in the other, heart pounding as I try to decide which role to honor first.
